title: AAQ: Is Evil The Highest Ignorance? Does It Have a Form? | His Grace Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa
speaker: HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa

segments.key_quote: The standard of what is evil, what is not evil, what is good, what is bad, all these things keep changing with time.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of whether evil is the highest degree of ignorance and argues that the definition of good and evil changes with time and societal norms, using examples like alcohol consumption and premarital relationships.

segments.key_quote: By today's standards, Ramana is a very good man.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of Ravana's abduction of Sita to illustrate how perceptions of good and evil change over time, contrasting the severe punishment Ravana faced in Vedic times with the relatively lenient punishments for similar crimes today.

segments.key_quote: What is good at one time becomes bad at another. What is bad at one time becomes good at another time.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to argue that the definition of evil changes with time, citing examples of intoxication and live-in relationships, and how societal views on these topics have shifted over the years.

segments.key_quote: All this consideration in the material world, everything is born of ignorance.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the concepts of good and bad in the material world are mental concoctions born of ignorance, using the analogy of wet and dry stool to illustrate that both are ultimately undesirable.

segments.key_quote: The only eternally good thing is surrendering unto Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes that only devotional service to Krishna is outside the realm of ignorance and that surrendering to Krishna is the only truly good thing, contrasting it with the ever-changing and ultimately ignorant notions of good and evil in the material world.
